metadata.title: Mutual Moral Respect (MMR) Scans Database
metadata.description: Comprehensive analysis of public figures across all categories - both those who pass and fail MMR standards

profiles.name: Maoz Inon & Aziz Abu Sara

pillars.evidence: Both lost family members to violence and advocate for civilian protection.
Abu Sara condemns Hamas violence while advocating for Palestinian rights.
Inon criticizes Israeli extremism and settlement expansion.
Both speak from personal experience and documented peace work.
Core mission is humanizing the other side through shared grief and hope.
Actively work together despite personal losses to promote coexistence.
Advocate for two-state solution with dignity for both peoples.

profiles.reflection: Exemplary MMR leadership through personal transformation of grief into bridge-building.

profiles.name: Gershon Baskin

pillars.evidence: Consistently advocates for civilian protection and opposes violence against all civilians.
Engages with Hamas for negotiations while maintaining criticism of violence.
Vocal critic of Israeli settlement expansion and occupation policies.
Draws on decades of mediation experience and documented peace initiatives.
Dedicated career to building bridges and understanding between communities.
Founded organizations specifically for Israeli-Palestinian cooperation.
Advocates for negotiated two-state solution with mutual recognition.

profiles.reflection: Veteran peace mediator with decades of bridge-building experience and consistent MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Sulaiman Khatib
profiles.role: Combatants for Peace, West Bank nonviolent activist

pillars.evidence: Former militant turned nonviolent activist, rejects all violence against civilians.
Openly criticizes militant approaches and advocates for nonviolent resistance.
Challenges occupation and settlement policies through nonviolent means.
Speaks from personal experience and documented activism with Combatants for Peace.
Works directly with former Israeli soldiers to build mutual understanding.
Co-leads binational movement for coexistence and mutual recognition.
Advocates for nonviolent path to Palestinian liberation and Israeli security.

profiles.reflection: Powerful example of transformation from militancy to nonviolent leadership with full MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Sally Abed

pillars.evidence: Advocates for civilian protection and opposes violence against all civilians.
Opposes militant violence while focusing on systemic change and equality.
Actively campaigns against discrimination and ultra-nationalist policies.
Transparent political work and documented activism with Standing Together.
Emphasizes 'radical empathy' between communities and shared struggles.
Seeks joint narratives and partnership through grassroots organizing.
Works toward grassroots political change and two-state solution through Standing Together.

profiles.reflection: Grassroots political leader demonstrating full MMR alignment through binational organizing.

profiles.name: Combatants for Peace

pillars.evidence: Founded on principle of nonviolence and civilian protection.
Palestinian members reject militant approaches, advocate nonviolence.
Israeli members critique military occupation and extremism.
Transparent documentation of activities and member testimonies.
Brings together former enemies to share stories and build empathy.
Core mission is coexistence and mutual recognition.
Bi-national nonviolent movement working toward peace and justice.

profiles.reflection: Transformative organization turning former combatants into peace advocates with exemplary MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Standing Together

pillars.evidence: Advocates for civilian protection and opposes violence against all civilians.
Opposes militant violence while focusing on systemic change.
Actively campaigns against occupation and ultra-nationalist policies.
Transparent grassroots organizing with documented activities.
Brings Arabs and Jews together for shared political action.
Core mission is equality and coexistence within shared society.
Works toward equality, social justice, and end of occupation.

profiles.reflection: Leading grassroots movement demonstrating practical coexistence and political change with full MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Women Wage Peace

pillars.evidence: Women-led advocacy for civilian protection and peace.
Advocates nonviolent approaches to conflict resolution.
Challenges militaristic approaches and occupation policies.
Transparent women's movement with documented activities.
Brings together women across ethnic and religious lines.
Collaborates across communities for shared peace vision.
Women-led peace movement with international recognition.

profiles.reflection: Women-led peace movement demonstrating cross-community collaboration with strong MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Benjamin Netanyahu

pillars.evidence: Rhetorically affirms minimizing civilian casualties but uses scorched-earth metaphors and praises military actions with high civilian tolls.
Repeatedly condemns Hamas's October 7 attack, labels them equivalent to ISIS.
Enables extremists in coalitions, tolerates anti-Palestinian discourse, does not condemn settler extremism.
Often speaks factually but sometimes selectively framed or hyperbolic.
Frames Palestinians collectively as threats; almost no empathetic tone towards Palestinian civilians.
Opposes Hamas eliminationism but tolerates Israeli domestic extremists.
Lacks any public framework for Palestinian dignity or state legitimacy; security-centered approach only.

profiles.reflection: Strong on Hamas accountability but fails on Israeli extremism, Palestinian empathy, and peace vision.

profiles.name: Itamar Ben-Gvir

pillars.evidence: Advocates collective punishment and policies that harm Palestinian civilians.
Strong condemnation of Hamas as genocidal.
Core far-right figure who promotes rather than critiques settler violence and ultra-nationalism.
Uses verified events but distorts framing with supremacist ideology.
Repeatedly dehumanizes Palestinians, questions their national identity and rights.
Explicitly opposes Palestinian statehood, advocates permanent subjugation.
No dignity-based or peace-oriented vision; advocates permanent control over Palestinians.

profiles.reflection: Represents eliminationist ultra-nationalism with clear failure across most MMR pillars.

profiles.name: Bezalel Smotrich

pillars.evidence: Called for Huwara to be 'wiped out,' defends settler violence, promotes military actions with civilian disregard.
Strong condemnation of Hamas as genocidal.
Core far-right figure who promotes rather than critiques settler violence and ultra-nationalism.
Uses verified events but distorts framing with supremacist ideology.
Dehumanizes Palestinians, denies their national identity, shows no empathy.
Advocates annexation and permanent subjugation of Palestinians.
Supports stability and security but does not articulate dignity-based peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Extremist politician promoting settler supremacism with clear MMR failure across most pillars.

profiles.name: Benny Gantz
profiles.role: National Unity Party leader, former Defense Minister

pillars.evidence: Supported humanitarian corridors but defended IDF operations with high civilian tolls; no consistent moral framing rejecting civilian harm.
Clearly blames Hamas for Oct 7 atrocities; supports dismantling militant networks.
Opposed far-right cabinet influence; resigned when civilian-focused governance was blocked.
Generally fact-based in public statements.
Centers Israeli trauma; limited empathy for Palestinian civilians.
Rejects extremist eliminationist rhetoric.
Security-focused approach; lacks comprehensive dignity-based peace framework.

profiles.reflection: Pragmatic centrist with some MMR alignment but falls short on civilian protection standards and Palestinian empathy.

profiles.name: Yair Lapid

pillars.evidence: Urged restraint after Gaza operations, called for minimizing civilian casualties.
Condemns October 7 as terror, supports dismantling Hamas capabilities.
Criticizes government's ultra-nationalist agenda, warns against annexation.
Cites human rights reports and operational data when critiquing actions.
Apologized for civilian suffering on both sides, emphasized shared humanity.
Advocates two-state solution and condemns extremist rhetoric on all sides.
Supports renewed negotiations but lacks detailed mutual dignity framework.

profiles.reflection: Centrist leader with strong accountability standards but limited on comprehensive peace vision.

profiles.name: Avigdor Lieberman

pillars.evidence: Supports military operations with limited concern for civilian impact.
Hardline against Hamas terror.
Opposes ultra-Orthodox influence but limited critique of settler extremism.
Generally grounded in security-based factual discourse.
Limited empathy for Palestinians; focuses on Israeli security concerns.
Opposes eliminationist framing.
Security-driven framing; lacks dignity-based peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Hardline security-focused politician with limited MMR alignment beyond Hamas accountability.

profiles.name: Naftali Bennett

pillars.evidence: Supports military operations with limited civilian protection standards.
Hardline against Hamas terror.
Center-right framing; little public critique of Israeli extremists.
Generally grounded in governance-based factual discourse.
Limited empathy for Palestinians.
Opposes eliminationist framing.
Security-driven framing; lacks dignity-based peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Pragmatic right-centrism but falls short of MMR leadership in empathy or peace-building.

profiles.name: Gideon Sa'ar

pillars.evidence: Supports military operations with limited civilian protection standards.
Hardline against Hamas terror.
Center-right framing; little public critique of Israeli extremists.
Generally grounded in governance-based factual discourse.
Limited empathy for Palestinians.
Opposes eliminationist framing.
Security-driven framing; lacks dignity-based peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Reflects pragmatic right-centrism but falls short of MMR leadership in empathy or peace-building.

profiles.name: Yair Golan

pillars.evidence: Condemned IDF excesses; upholds moral norms.
Consistently denounces Hamas terror.
Publicly warns against Israeli fascism.
Grounded in verified sources and military knowledge.
Speaks of Palestinian dignity and rights.
Opposes all forms of eliminationist ideology.
Advocates for a shared future rooted in dignity.

profiles.reflection: Exemplifies clear MMR-aligned voice — balancing accountability, empathy, and vision of shared dignity.

profiles.name: Mahmoud Abbas

pillars.evidence: Stated: 'We reject the practices of killing civilians or abusing them on both sides...' — clear rejection of civilian targeting.
Called Hamas 'sons of dogs,' demanded hostages be released, stated Oct 7 attacks 'don't represent Palestinians.'
Consistently called out Israeli far-right violence and settler extremism in UN forums.
Grounds public statements in UN resolutions, international law, and credible casualty data.
Highlights Palestinian suffering and Israeli hostages but less empathy for Israeli civilian fears.
Advocates two-state solution, rejects collective enmity.
Pushed for ceasefire, PA-led governance in Gaza, and long-term two-state peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Demonstrates moral clarity and leadership— condemning civilian harm, rebuking Hamas, asserting international justice, and envisioning Palestinian statehood. Could deepen MMR by more fully acknowledging Israeli civilian fears.

profiles.name: Hussein al-Sheikh

pillars.evidence: Advocates for civilian protection and condemns targeting of innocents.
Supports political integration of Hamas while opposing violence.
Criticizes Israeli settlement expansion and extremist policies.
Bases statements on documented policies and international law.
Frames Hamas as part of the people needing reform, not eradication.
Advocates for political solutions and integration rather than elimination.
Works toward Palestinian statehood through diplomatic and political means.

profiles.reflection: Presents forward-looking stance — backing ceasefire, political integration, and eventual statehood with consistent MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Majed Faraj

pillars.evidence: Limited public statements on civilian protection standards.
Security cooperation against militants but limited public moral accountability.
Limited public criticism of Israeli extremism.
Limited public statements to assess sourcing standards.
Limited public statements on humanization.
Security role suggests pragmatic approach but limited public statements.
Security-focused role with limited public peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Intelligence role limits public MMR assessment; appears pragmatic but insufficient public data for full evaluation.

profiles.name: Rami Hamdallah

pillars.evidence: Advocated for non-violence and civilian protection during tenure.
Criticized incitement and called for Palestinian unity, but muted on specific Hamas accountability.
Called out Israeli settler violence and ultra-nationalist rhetoric.
Grounded in UN and international law references, but political framing at times outweighs transparent sourcing.
Advocated for non-violence and rights for both Palestinians and Israelis.
Consistently promoted peaceful resolution and opposed extremism.
Advocated for two-state solution grounded in mutual dignity.

profiles.reflection: Consistently supported peaceful, rights-based solutions and non-violence, though less direct in confronting Hamas rejectionism. Reflects constructive moderate voice within the PA.

profiles.name: Yahya Sinwar

pillars.evidence: Orchestrated October 7 attacks targeting Israeli civilians; frames civilian casualties as acceptable for resistance.
Hamas leader who justifies and directs militant operations; no self-accountability.
Frames all Israelis as legitimate targets; no moral distinction between civilians and extremists.
Uses propaganda and inflammatory rhetoric rather than verified information.
Dehumanizes Israelis as occupiers and enemies; shows no empathy for Israeli civilians.
Advocates for elimination of Israel and supports armed struggle until total victory.
No peace vision; only continued resistance and armed struggle until Israeli defeat.

profiles.reflection: Represents eliminationist militancy with complete failure across all MMR pillars.

profiles.name: Khaled Meshaal

pillars.evidence: Explicitly endorsed Oct 7 attacks, which targeted Israeli civilians; consistently framed violence against civilians as justified 'resistance.'
Top Hamas rejectionist leader; no evidence of moral accountability for Hamas actions.
Denounces Israeli policies rhetorically but in polarizing, dehumanizing terms, without distinction between Israeli far-right and broader Israeli public.
Relies on ideological, propagandistic framing; no consistent use of verified sources.
Frames Israelis collectively as occupiers/enemies; no evidence of empathy toward Israeli civilians.
Advocates elimination of Israel through armed resistance; rejects coexistence.
No peace framework beyond continued resistance; rejects mutual recognition.

profiles.reflection: Embodies eliminationist rhetoric: praising civilian-targeted violence, rejecting mutual recognition, and framing perpetual jihad as the solution.

profiles.name: Mousa Abu Marzook

pillars.evidence: Defends Oct 7 attacks despite civilian targeting; frames civilian harm as unavoidable resistance consequence.
Hamas leadership position; defends all Hamas actions without moral accountability.
Frames all Israelis as aggressors; no moral distinction between civilians and extremists.
Uses ideological framing and propaganda rather than verified sources.
Dehumanizing rhetoric toward Israelis; no empathy for Israeli civilians.
Supports Hamas eliminationist ideology and armed struggle until Israeli defeat.
No vision beyond resistance and struggle; rejects shared dignity concepts.

profiles.reflection: Hamas deputy leader promoting eliminationist ideology with complete MMR failure across all pillars.

profiles.name: Osama Hamdan

pillars.evidence: Justifies Oct 7 civilian targeting as legitimate resistance; denies Hamas responsibility for civilian harm.
Official Hamas spokesperson defending all actions; no internal accountability.
Frames all Israelis as aggressors; no moral distinction between civilians and extremists.
Spreads conspiracy theories and denies documented Hamas actions; propaganda-based messaging.
Dehumanizing rhetoric toward Israelis; no empathy for Israeli civilians.
Promotes Hamas eliminationist ideology and rejects coexistence.
No peace vision; only continued resistance until Israeli defeat.

profiles.reflection: Official Hamas spokesperson promoting denialism and eliminationist ideology with complete MMR failure.

profiles.name: Sami Abu Zuhri

pillars.evidence: Justifies mass killing of Israeli civilians as 'legitimate resistance.'
Spokesperson defending all Hamas actions — no internal accountability.
Frames all Israelis as aggressors; no moral distinction.
Public statements use inflammatory rhetoric; no fact-based grounding.
Dehumanizing rhetoric toward Israelis; no empathy for civilians.
Supports Hamas eliminationist ideology.
No vision beyond resistance and struggle; rejects shared dignity concepts.

profiles.reflection: Abu Zuhri's role centers on promoting Hamas's rejectionist and eliminationist ideology — fails every MMR pillar by example.

profiles.name: Rep. Ritchie Torres

pillars.evidence: Clear and repeated moral condemnation of Hamas, calling them a genocidal terrorist organization. Criticizes Palestinian Authority's glorification of violence and failure to embrace peaceful state-building. Explicit that Palestinian leadership bears responsibility for rejectionist stances.

Clear and repeated moral condemnation of Hamas, calling them a genocidal terrorist organization. Criticizes Palestinian Authority's glorification of violence and failure to embrace peaceful state-building.

One of the few vocal American politicians calling out Israeli ultranationalist figures (e.g., Ben-Gvir, Smotrich). Warns against annexation, creeping authoritarianism, and erosion of democratic norms in Netanyahu's coalition. Calls for holding Israeli extremists accountable.
Bases statements on hostage-taking, war crime claims, and ICC process.
Highlights Palestinian suffering and Israeli hostages but less empathy for Israeli civilian fears.
Advocates two-state solution, rejects collective enmity.
Pushed for ceasefire, PA-led governance in Gaza, and long-term two-state peace vision.

profiles.reflection: Torres demonstrates moral clarity and leadership— condemning civilian harm, rebuking Hamas, asserting international justice, and envisioning Palestinian statehood. He could deepen MMR by more fully acknowledging Israeli civilian fears.

profiles.name: Mehdi Hasan

pillars.evidence: Repeatedly condemned the killing of civilians on both sides.
Condemned Hamas war crimes but avoids clear labeling of Hamas as terrorist; emphasis leans toward Israeli accountability.
Consistently criticizes Israeli far-right figures and policies.
Highly fact-based, with legal and verified sourcing.
Centers Palestinian suffering; less public empathy toward Israeli civilian trauma.
Opposes eliminationist ideologies.
Advocates justice-focused approach but limited comprehensive peace framework.

profiles.reflection: Strong journalistic standards and Israeli accountability, but limited Hamas accountability and Palestinian-centered framing reduces full MMR alignment.

profiles.name: Christiane Amanpour

pillars.evidence: Consistently condemns civilian targeting by all parties.
Reports on Hamas actions and holds them accountable for violence.
Covers Israeli government policies and extremist actions critically.
Renowned for rigorous fact-checking and verified reporting.
Gives voice to civilians on both sides; empathetic interviewing style.
Opposes extremist narratives; promotes dialogue and understanding.
Focuses on current events reporting rather than comprehensive peace frameworks.

profiles.reflection: Veteran journalist with strong MMR alignment through balanced, empathetic reporting and rigorous standards.

profiles.name: Anderson Cooper

pillars.evidence: Condemns civilian casualties and highlights human cost of conflict.
Reports on Hamas actions and their impact on civilians.
Covers Israeli policies and their effects on Palestinian civilians.
Known for fact-based reporting and verification standards.
Focuses on human stories and civilian experiences on both sides.
Avoids inflammatory rhetoric; focuses on factual reporting.
News reporting role limits explicit peace advocacy.

profiles.reflection: Solid journalistic standards with balanced human-focused reporting, though limited by news format constraints.

profiles.name: Clarissa Ward

pillars.evidence: Extensive on-ground reporting highlighting civilian suffering.
Reports on militant actions and their consequences for civilians.
Covers Israeli military actions and policy impacts.
Rigorous field reporting with verified sources and documentation.
Powerful human interest reporting from conflict zones.
Focuses on human cost rather than political rhetoric.
Reporting role limits explicit peace advocacy.

profiles.reflection: Exceptional conflict correspondent with strong humanitarian focus and balanced reporting standards.

profiles.name: Jeremy Bowen

pillars.evidence: Longstanding condemnation of civilian targeting.
Reports accurately on Hamas rejectionist actions.
Covers Israeli far-right trends and actions.
Highly regarded for depth, accuracy, and context.
Empathetic reporting toward civilians on all sides.
Frames reporting through rights and dignity.
Gives voice to actors supporting coexistence and dignity.

profiles.reflection: MMR-aligned journalist whose balanced, rights-based reporting consistently affirms empathy and dignity for all civilians.

profiles.name: Omar Shakir

pillars.evidence: Condemns targeting of civilians by all sides; HRW reports under his leadership have documented Israeli and Palestinian violations.
HRW under Shakir's leadership documents Hamas abuses but public statements often foreground Israeli violations over clear moral agency for Hamas leadership.
Extensively documents and critiques Israeli ultra-nationalist policies and abuses.
HRW investigations under Shakir are known for rigorous verification and documentation.
Centering Palestinian suffering; limited empathy toward Israeli civilian fears and trauma.
Advocates universal human rights; rejects eliminationist frames.
Justice-oriented framing; lacks detailed vision for mutual dignity peace.

profiles.reflection: Strong human rights documentation but leans justice-centered — offering limited Hamas accountability and mutual empathy.

profiles.name: Hagai El-Ad

pillars.evidence: Condemns civilian targeting; focuses on Israeli military actions affecting Palestinian civilians.
Limited focus on Hamas accountability; primarily critiques Israeli actions.
Extensive documentation and criticism of Israeli occupation and settler violence.
B'Tselem known for rigorous field documentation and verification.
Centers Palestinian suffering; limited empathy for Israeli civilian concerns.
Advocates human rights for all; opposes eliminationist rhetoric.
Rights-focused approach; limited comprehensive peace framework.

profiles.reflection: Strong Israeli human rights advocate but limited on Hamas accountability and mutual empathy.

profiles.name: Yuli Novak

pillars.evidence: Documents and opposes military actions that harm civilians.
Limited focus on Hamas; primarily documents Israeli military conduct.
Breaking the Silence extensively documents military abuses and occupation policies.
Organization known for soldier testimonies and verified documentation.
Focuses on humanizing Palestinian experiences; some empathy for Israeli soldiers' moral dilemmas.
Advocates for accountability and change rather than elimination.
Works toward ending occupation and promoting accountability for peace.

profiles.reflection: Strong Israeli military accountability advocate with good MMR alignment, though limited on Hamas accountability.

profiles.name: Kenneth Roth
profiles.role: Former Human Rights Watch Executive Director

pillars.evidence: Condemns targeting of civilians by all parties.
Under Roth's leadership, HRW often foregrounded Israeli violations over moral agency for Hamas leadership.
Critiques Israeli state policies and ultra-nationalist figures.
Built HRW's reputation on rigorous, verified human rights documentation.
Centers Palestinian suffering; less articulation of Israeli civilian trauma.
Advocates universal human rights; rejects eliminationist frames.
Justice-oriented framing; lacks detailed vision for mutual dignity peace.

profiles.reflection: Built global rights accountability but leaned justice-centered — offering limited humanization and future dignity vision.
